1.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The Clearwater Paper Corporation operates Cypress Bend Mill (Clearwater) and has a long-standing commitment to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, the Arkansas Pulp and Paperboard Division in McGehee, Arkansas, has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at its facility. One component of this system is a risk management plan (RMP) that helps manage the risks at Clearwater and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Risk Management Plan Rule (the Rule).  One of the requirements of the Rule is to submit an RMP describing the risk management program at Clearwater. This document is intended to satisfy the RMP requirement of the Rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Clearwater.



2.0  REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Clearwater is an integrated bleached kraft mill that employs approximately 365 full-time workers. Clearwater produces approximately 950 tons per day of bleached kraft pulp and operates a coated paperboard machine.  To support these operations, Clearwater handles two regulated substances in sufficient quantities to be covered by the Rule: chlorine and chlorine dioxide. 



The Rule requires all regulated toxic substances contained in 40 CFR 68 that are stored in quantities above the specified thresholds to be included in an RMP. Chlorine is present in pressurized containers above the threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds at three distinct locations and chlorine dioxide is present in a chilled aqueous solution in storage tanks above the threshold quantity of 1,000 pounds. 3.0  HAZARD ASSESSMENT



Clearwater performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance to affect the public or the environment. The offsite consequence analysis consists of evaluating both worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios. Clearwater does not expect a worst-case release scenario to ever occur. An alternative release scenario represents a release that both might occur at a facility similar to Clearwater and would result in the greatest potential offsite consequences if the release occurred. By identifying these potential releases, Clearwater has prepared an extensive program to prevent such an occurrence. This program is discussed in detail in the "Prevention Program" section of this plan.



The primary objective of performing the offsite consequences analysis is to determine the distance at which the public and/or the environment might be affected in the event of an accidental release.  This point is called the endpoint distance.  At distances less than the endpoint distance, the effects would be greater; at distances greater than the endpoint, the effects would be less.  The offsite consequence analysis can be found within the Hazard Assessment Documentation section of the RMP.



4.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (PROGRAM 3)



Since Clearwater's inception in 1977, the mill has used a prevention program to help prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances. Beginning in 1992, Clearwater formalized this prevention program for the Chlorine Unloading and Transfer and the Chlorine Dioxide Generation, Storage, and Transfer, and the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and Transfer processes to comply with the 14 elements of the Occupational Safety and Health

Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) prevention program. In 1996, the Rule established similar requirements for Program 3 processes. In September 2000, chlorine for pulp bleaching and anhydrous ammonia was removed from service and is no longer present at Clearwater. The following sections briefly describe the elements of Clearwater's Program 3 prevention program that address the Rule prevention program requirements.



4.1  Process Safety Information



To ensure the safety of our processes, equipment complies with good engineering practices and a variety of technical documents are maintained.  These documents address:

?    physical properties of hazardous substances handled,

?    chemical properties and associated hazards of those substances, and

?    design basis and configuration of the equipment.



Clearwater ensures that this process safety information is available to all Clearwater employees and local fire and emergency response personnel and that the process safety information is kept up to date.



Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) document the physical properties of hazardous substances handled at Clearwater, including regulated substances in RMP-covered processes. SDSs for hazardous substances handled in each process are available to mill operators for ready reference.  The SDSs for covered processes include the information outlined in 40 CFR 68.65(b).



The engineering design documents include the operating parameters and the design basis and configuration of the equipment in each covered process. The available information includes:

?    operating parameters,

?    block flow or simplified process flow diagrams,

?    process chemistry,

?    maximum intended inventories,

?    safe upper and lower limits for parameters such as temperature, pressure or flow,

?    consequences of deviation from established operating limits,

?    design basis and configuration of equipment (materials of construction),

?    piping and instrument diagrams, including materials of constructio

n,

?    electrical classification,

?    safety systems,

?    applicable design codes and standards, and

?    design basis for relief and ventilation systems.



When important information was not available from the design documents, it was developed through special projects. Many of the operating parameters are included in the operating procedures to help with the safe operation of the process. These documents are used to:

?    train employees,

?    perform Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs), and

?    help maintain the equipment.



All the above-mentioned information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the processes are not compromised.



4.2  Process Hazard Analysis



Clearwater performs and periodically updates Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) of the covered processes to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process. A team composed of personnel with engineering and process operating experience and a leader with PHA experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of the process. 



Clearwater primarily uses the hazard and operability study (HAZOP) to perform this analysis as allowed by the Rule under ?68.67(b)(4). The PHA team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis including findings from all incident investigations required under ?68.81, any other potential failure scenarios, and a list of recommendations. Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to mill personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the process are implemented. 



4.3  Operating Procedures



Clearwater engineers, operators, and supervisors work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating pr

ocedures serve two main functions.  First, they are used to train employees. Second, they serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets. Clearwater employees develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including:

?    initial startup,

?    normal operations,

?    normal shutdown,

?    emergency shutdown,

?    startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown, and

?    temporary operations.



The written operating procedures include:

?    steps for safely conducting process tasks,

?    applicable process safety information such as safe operating limits and consequences of process deviations, and

?    safety and health considerations such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and the action(s) to take in the event of an exposure to a hazardous substance.



4.4  Training



Clearwater trains workers, including supervisors with process operational responsibilities, to perform their assigned tasks safely and effectively. The Clearwater training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers:

?    a general overview of the process,

?    the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and

?    a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.



Employees that work closely with hazardous chemicals receive specialized training for operation and maintenance of process equipment. Demonstrations and employee observations are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the employee can resume work in the process.



4.5  Mechanical Integrity



Clearwater maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. The mechanical integrity program includes:

?    an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails,

?    a quality assurance prog

ram to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in the process,

?    specifications for inspection and testing of process equipment,

?    specifications for replacement parts and equipment,

?    procedures for inspecting, testing, and maintaining process equipment,

?    procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, hot work, confined space entry and line or equipment opening,

?    training of maintenance personnel, and

?    documentation of maintenance activities.



4.6  Management of Change



The Clearwater management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without completing a full management of change process. All other changes must be confirmed through the full management of change review to help ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.



4.7  Pre-startup Review



Clearwater performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into service to help ensure that the process has been prepared to operate safely. This review confirms that:

?    construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications,

?    adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place,

?    employee training has been completed, and

?    for covered processes, a PHA has been performed for new processes and management of change requirements have been completed for modified processes.



A pre-startup review checklist is completed to document the review and to ensure that appropriate issues have been addressed.

4.8  Compliance Audit



Clearwater audits each covered processes to be certain that the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of Clearwater operations at least every three years. Clearwater assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Rule and in the process, and this team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.



4.9  Incident Investigation



Clearwater investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment (i.e., near misses) so that similar accidents can be prevented. Clearwater trains employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the investigation are documented as described in the Rule under ?68.81(d) within 12 months of the incident, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented. 



4.10  Employee Participation



Clearwater developed a written employee participation program for covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of Clearwater employees are addressed. Clearwater encourages active participation of personnel in the prevention program activities of all processes at the mill. Employees are consulted on and informed about all aspects of the RMP, including PHAs, employee training, and operating procedures.



4.11  Hot Work Permits



Clearwater established a hot work permit program to control spark-producing or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions in covered processes at the mill. Clearwater reviewed OSHA's fire prevention and protect

ion requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) and created a Hot Work Permit Form to comply with these requirements. Personnel who are to perform hot work are required to fill out the Hot Work Permit Form. The Shift Supervisor reviews the completed form before work can begin.

 

4.12  Contractors



Clearwater established a program to help ensure that contractor activities at Clearwater are performed in a safe manner. The program reviews the safety record of all contractors to help ensure that only contractors who can safely perform the desired job tasks are hired. Clearwater trains the contract supervisors in the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, in Clearwater safe work practices, and in mill emergency response procedures. Clearwater requires that the contractor supervisors train each of their employees who will work at the mill before that worker begins work at the site. Clearwater periodically reviews contractor training documents and work performance to help ensure that safe work practices are followed. 



5.0  CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In addition to the required prevention program elements, Clearwater has implemented safety features specific to the hazardous substances used at the mill. 

?    Chlorine specific release prevention is the use of the one-ton cylinders in water treatment in all chlorine processes located at various locations around Clearwater. These cylinders provide passive security against potential releases. 

?    Chlorine dioxide is produced at Clearwater and stored as a dilute aqueous solution to avoid the necessity of transporting large quantities of the solution. Chlorine dioxide is produced in the chlorine dioxide generator and piped to an absorber column where a maximum of 1.5% by weight chlorine dioxide solution is generated. Storing this substance as a solution helps to reduce the consequences of a release. A curbed area around the storage tanks further reduces the consequences of a release.



6.0  FI

VE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Clearwater has had no releases during the last five years of chlorine dioxide that have resulted in any offsite public or environmental effects or that have resulted in employee first aid treatment.



Clearwater had two releases of chlorine during the last five years that resulted in offsite public or environmental effects or in employee first aid treatment.  



The first incident occurred on January 18, 2018 and lasted less than one minute.  The employee was changing out an empty chlorine cylinder and was exposed to chlorine gas trapped in the vaporizer/chlorinator assembly.  First aid was administered as needed.  The procedure was reviewed for clarity and refresher training was held on leak detection, scenarios for potential gas release, and past history of gas release and mechanical failures.



The second incident occurred on May 2, 2021 and lasted for 29 hours.  Due to a control valve failure in the chlorine dioxide delivery system, excess chlorine dioxide was charged to the process.  It was determined that the safest alternative to remedy the immediate issue was to allow the extra chlorine dioxide gas to off in the washer hoods and into the bleach plant scrubber.  The employee completed sampling in the affected area while chlorine sensors were not sounding an alarm without use of a respirator.  The procedure was reviewed resulting in the establishment of a new PM for the problem part. Chlorine alarms were also revised so that monitors on the operate floor sound at 0.5 ppm rather than 1 ppm.  Respiratory awareness training was completed with all employees.



7.0  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS



Clearwater has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. The emergency response plan includes procedures for:

?    informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases,

?    providing proper first aid and emergency treatment for human ex

posure to hazardous substances at Clearwater,

?    controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances, including the use of emergency response equipment,

?    inspecting and maintaining emergency response equipment, and

?    reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.



Clearwater operates a trained and well-equipped emergency response group to respond to emergencies within the mill. All mill employees are trained in evacuation procedures and the Clearwater first-responder group periodically conducts emergency response drills. The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations (e.g., 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 29 CFR 1910.120(a)) and has been communicated to the local authorities.



8.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Clearwater Paper Corporation continuously strives to improve the safety of our processes through incident investigation, PHAs, and employee suggestions.  Our engineering and technical personnel stay abreast of technology advancements, which may improve the safety of our processes.
